thread.title: Senators reach deal to reduce prison time for some offenders
thread.title_full: Senators reach deal to reduce prison time for some offenders - San Francisco Chronicle

author: Mary Clare Jalonick, Associated Press
title: Senators reach deal to reduce prison time for some offenders
text: Photo: Jacquelyn Martin, AP Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, right, shakes hands with the committee's ranking member Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., during a news conference on Capitol Hill in Washington, Thursday, Oct. 1, 2015, where a bipartisan group of Senators spoke about criminal justice reform. The group unveiled legislation that would overhaul the nation’s criminal justice system, allowing some non-violent drug offenders to get reduced prison sentences and giving judges greater discretion in sentencing.. Senate Minority Whip Richard Durbin of Ill. is at left. Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa,... WASHINGTON (AP) — Senate conservatives and liberals on Thursday united behind an overhaul of the criminal justice system, a rare bipartisan agreement that would allow some nonviolent drug offenders to get reduced prison sentences and give judges greater discretion in sentencing. Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, right, shakes hands with the committee's ranking member Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., during a news conference on Capitol Hill in Washington, Thursday, Oct. 1, 2015, where a bipartisan group of Senators spoke about criminal justice reform. The group unveiled legislation that would overhaul the nation’s criminal justice system, allowing some non-violent drug offenders to get reduced prison sentences and giving judges greater discretion in sentencing.. Senate Minority Whip Richard Durbin of Ill. is at left. Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa,... WASHINGTON (AP) — Senate conservatives and liberals on Thursday united behind an overhaul of the criminal justice system, a rare bipartisan agreement that would allow some nonviolent drug offenders to get reduced prison sentences and give judges greater discretion in sentencing.
